title: 115_s2584
content: The Act is titled the "Student Non-Discrimination Act of 2018" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The Student Non-Discrimination Act of 2018 acknowledges pervasive discrimination against LGBT students in public schools, including harassment, bullying, and violence, leading to unequal educational opportunities nationwide. Discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity is highlighted as a severe issue inadequately addressed by current Federal law. Studies show that such discrimination in schools contributes to high rates of negative outcomes. Discrimination in schools based on sexual orientation or gender identity leads to negative outcomes like absenteeism, academic underachievement, dropping out, and adverse health consequences among LGBT youth. This discrimination can escalate to life-threatening violence and suicide if not addressed promptly. Federal statutory law prohibits discrimination based on various factors, but discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity remains a significant issue in public schools. The absence of express Federal law prohibitions on discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity has created uncertainty, limiting access to legal remedies for LGBT students and their parents. The purposes of this Act are to ensure all students have a safe, discrimination-free environment in public education. The Act aims to provide explicit Federal prohibition of discrimination in public schools based on sexual orientation or gender identity, offer effective remedies for such discrimination, and utilize congressional powers to enforce these protections. The Act aims to prohibit discrimination in public schools based on sexual orientation or gender identity, allowing the Department of Education and the Department of Justice to enforce regulations effectively. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS AND RULE. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to education and harassment, including "educational agency," "gender identity," and "harassment." The curr_chunk defines acts of aggression, intimidation, or hostility based on sexual orientation or gender identity in educational settings. It also clarifies terms like "program or activity" and "public school." The curr_chunk defines terms related to education, including "sexual orientation," "student," and the interpretation of the term "includes" in the Act. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity in programs receiving Federal financial assistance. The curr_chunk defines "opposition to conduct made unlawful by this Act" as including reporting conduct believed to be unlawful or that could become unlawful under the Act. The curr_chunk outlines protected activities under the Act, including participation in investigations or hearings related to unlawful conduct, and providing assistance to others in exercising their rights. It emphasizes that false information should not be purposefully provided to public schools or governmental entities regarding unlawful conduct. Activities believed to be unlawful or could become unlawful under this Act if allowed to continue. SEC. 5. Federal administrative enforcement; report to congressional committees. Each Federal department and agency providing financial assistance to education programs must comply with section 4 by issuing rules approved by the President. Non-compliance may result in termination of assistance to recipients. The termination or refusal of assistance to recipients due to noncompliance with requirements must be based on an express finding after a hearing. The action is limited to the specific entity and program where noncompliance occurred, and other means authorized by law can also be used. The department must notify the appropriate individuals of the noncompliance before taking any action. The head of the Federal department or agency must report to Congress if assistance is denied due to noncompliance with requirements. The action cannot take effect until 30 days after the report is filed. SEC. 6. PRIVATE CAUSE OF ACTION. Private Cause of Action allows aggrieved individuals to bring a court action for violations of the Act, similar to other civil rights laws. Remedies may include equitable relief, compensatory damages, and costs. The section does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under other laws or require exhausting administrative processes before seeking redress. Statute of limitations for actions under this section will be determined accordingly. The statute of limitations for actions under the Private Cause of Action section will be determined in accordance with section 1658(a) of title 28, United States Code, with tolling governed by the law of the State where the action is brought. SEC. 7. The Attorney General can file a civil action in a US district court for violations of this Act, seeking appropriate relief including compensatory damages. The Attorney General can intervene in ongoing actions and receive the same relief. Individuals still have the right to sue for violations of this Act. SEC. 8. States are not immune to legal action under this Act. SEC. 8. State Immunity - States are not immune to legal action in Federal court for violations of this Act, and receiving Federal financial assistance constitutes a waiver of sovereign immunity. Remedies are available for violations to the same extent as against any other entity. SEC. 9. Attorney's Fees. SEC. 9. Attorney's Fees amended to include the Student Non-Discrimination Act of 2018. SEC. 10. Effect on other laws. The Act does not override existing Federal and State nondiscrimination laws, including titles IV and VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations of this Act are additional to those imposed by existing laws. The Act does not override existing Federal and State nondiscrimination laws, including titles IV and VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations of this Act are additional to those imposed by existing laws. Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, and section 1979 of the Revised Statutes are also referenced. The Act does not affect legal standards for freedom of speech and expression, including rights available to religious and other student groups under the First Amendment and the Equal Access Act. SEVERABILITY: If any part of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. EFFECTIVE DATE: The Act will take effect 60 days after enactment and does not apply to conduct before that date.
